About this tutorial

You'll learn how to use Types and Views to create a fully-functional Real-Estate site with WordPress, without any coding. Video Overview (5 minutes)
It’s possible to create many different complex websites with Types and Views, without having to carry out any difficult coding. You may think that producing a Real Estate theme is beyond your knowledge, that it might be stretching you a little bit too far – but Types and Views takes care of that for you, letting you concentrate on design while it takes care of all of the work. This tutorial will show you how to put together a Real Estate website using Types and Views. Once you’ve got the basics you’ll be able to style it however you want. You can check out our demo site right here. Before you display your content, you will have to create it. You can use Types to create Custom Post Types, Taxonomies and Custom Fields. Here’s what you will need: Custom Post Type: Listings (Listing (s)) Display sections: Title, Editor, Custom Fields Custom Taxonomy: Listing Types (Listing Type (s)) Custom Field Group: Property Containing:
  • Image – Image Field
  • Custom Text – Single Line
  • Price – Numeric Field
  • Address – Single Line
  • City – Single Line
  • ZIP – Single Line
  • MLS – Single Line
  • Square Feet – Single Line
  • Bedrooms – Single Line
  • Bathrooms – Single Line
  • Maps – Text Area
  • Video – Text Area
Content: Add content to three listings, ensuring to upload images (remote images will not resize correctly) Content Taxonomy: Add “featured” and “slider” term in the Listing Types taxonomy to each listing. CSS: [code lang="css"] body.home .entry-title { display: none; } #wpv-front-page-slider { width: 500px; border: 1px solid #6D6D6D; margin-bottom: 20px; } #wpv-front-page-slider p { padding: 0; margin: 0; } #wpv-featured img { border: 1px solid #6D6D6D; margin-bottom: 10px; } .wpv-featured-link:link, .wpv-featured-link:visited { padding: 5px 10px; background-color: #333333; color: #FFFFFF; font-weight: bold; line-height: 45px; } body.single-listing .entry-content p { width: 600px; margin: 20px 0 20px 0; } body.single-listing .wpcf-field-name { font-weight: bold; } body.single-listing h3 { margin: 30px 0 20px 0; } body.single-listing .gallery .gallery-item { width: 180px !important; text-align: left !important; } body.single-listing img { border: 1px solid #6D6D6D !important; } .wpv-grand-listing { margin: 40px 0 40px 0; } .wpv-grand-listing thead { background-color: #F2F1F0; } .wpv-grand-listing thead a:link { color: #000000; } .wpv-grand-listing tbody td { background-color: #F7F6F5; padding: 10px; } [/code] You should add this CSS to your theme’s style.css. This will style the different fields and shortcodes we are using. You can change the styles to match your own theme should you wish. When you’re set up with all of this you’ll be able to create complex ways of displaying it. Here’s the homepage: And here is a single listings page: And here is a list of all of the properties: Before we get started let’s take a look at the composition of each page. The home page has two Views on it:
  1. A View for the slider, which displays a View Template
  2. A View for the Featured listings, which displays a View Template
Each single listing is created using a View Template: The overall listing page is created using another View. We have been able to insert a hyperlinked thumbnail image into the View using a View Template. This means that overall we must create the following: View Templates:
  1. Listings Slider Item
  2. Listing Featured item
  3. Single Listing
  4. Small-photo
Views
  1. Homepage slider
  2. Homepage featured listings
  3. Main listings page
You should already have created your Custom Post Types, Taxonomies and Custom Fields, as well as adding some content to your Listings. If you have not done this yet please return to the start of the tutorial and create the content required in the table. If you need help creating this content please follow this tutorial.

1) Create View Template: Listings Slider Item

This View Template is used as a template for the content that is displayed in the Listings Slider on the real estate homepage. To create it navigate to View Template > Add New Call your View Template: Listings Slider Item On our homepage slider we want to include:
  • Image of the property
  • Hyperlinked image
This is simple to include. All we need to do is insert the image field and surround it with a href with the post url. If you click on the V icon you’ll get a list of all the shortcodes available to you. [box type="info"]Tip: Views picks up all of the shortcodes in your WordPress installation which makes it great for integrating with other plugins.[/box] Here’s the code that you’ll need to create the Listings slider item template [code lang="html"] <a href="{{wpv-post-url}}" title="{{wpv-post-title}}">{{types field="image" alt="" title="" width="494" proportional="true" align="none"}}</a> [/code] {{box type= "info"}} You can adjust the width to fit your own theme.[/box] Click Publish.

2) Create View Template: Listing Featured Item

This View Template controls the size of the images in the Featured Listings on the homepage. Here’s what it looks like: Call your View Template: Listing Featured Item You can see from the image that we want to display the following:
  • The image, hyperlinked to the listings page
  • Price
  • Address
  • A “View Listing” link
Here is the code: [code lang="html"] <a href="{{wpv-post-url}}">{{types field="image" width="280" height="200" proportional="true" align="none"}}</a> <strong>Price:</strong> {{types field="price" format="$FIELD_VALUE"}} {{types field='address'}} <a href="{{wpv-post-url}}" class="wpv-featured-link">View Listing</a> [/code] Click Publish.

3) Create View Template: Listing

This View Template controls the display of the content on the Listing Page. You can see it in action here. As you can see, this displays all of the information that we have put into your custom fields. Navigate to View Templates > Add New Call this View Template: Listing You need to insert the shortcodes for the following:
  • Price
  • Address
  • City
  • State
  • Zip
  • MLS
  • Square Feet
  • Bedrooms
  • Bathrooms
  • Basement
  • Image
  • Map
You also want to insert the WordPress gallery shortcode. This inserts all of the images attached to a listing onto the page. Like so: You need the text from the custom fields to have labels so when displaying the custom fields you can use the parameter show_name=’true’ Here is the code: [code lang="html"] <div style="float:right;width: 320px"> <h3>Property Details</h3> {{types field="price" format="<strong>FIELD_NAME:</strong> $FIELD_VALUE"}}<br /> {{types field='address' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /> {{types field='city' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /> {{types field='state' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /> {{types field='zip' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /> {{types field='mls' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /> {{types field='square-feet' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /> {{types field='bedrooms' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /> {{types field='bathrooms' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /> {{types field='basement' show_name='true' output='html'}}<br /><br /> </div> {{types field="image" width="600" proportional="true" align="none" alt="" title=""}} <br /><br /> {{wpv-post-body view_template='None'}} <h3>Property Map</h3> {{types field='map'}} <h3>Additional Photos</h3> {{gallery link="file" columns="4" orderby="title"}} [/code] This View template needs to be attached to the Listing post type. This means that every listing you create will have this template applied to it. Navigate to Views > Settings. You'll see some tables, one to attach View Templates to archive loops, another to attach View Templates to post types. Here you can attach the listing View Template to the listing post type. Click Publish.

4) Create View Template: small-photo

This View Template is used to display the small images on the main listing page: Navigate to View Template > Add New Call your View Template: small-photo This is just a small image that is hyperlinked to the main listing. So we need to include the following:
  • Small image
  • Hyperlink
Here’s the code: [code lang="html" wraplines="true"] <a href="{{wpv-post-url}}">{{types field="image" width="80" height="60" proportional="true" align="none"}}</a> [/code] Click Publish. Now that you have created your View Templates you’re ready to create your Views.

5) Create View: Listings Featured

The Featured Listings are displayed on the homepage. These are listings that you have tagged with “Featured” in the Listings Taxonomy. Navigate to Views > Add New Call your View: Listings Featured You’ll see two shortcodes already there:
  • {{wpv-filter-meta-html}}
  • {{wpv-layout-meta-html}}
Do not remove these shortcodes. These are the shortcodes that filter and display your View. This is what we want to achieve with our Listings Featured View:
  • Filter the listings posts by post date, descending
  • Select posts with the listings term in the Listings Taxonomies taxonomy
  • Display the posts in a horizontal AJAX slider
  • Display the listing-featured-item View Template
There are a number of different steps that you need to carry out to create your View.

a) Filter

Scroll down to View Query > Filter and click “edit” Select “Listings”, order by post date, descending. Now you need to filter to only show the “Featured” items in the Listing Types taxonomy. Click “Add another filter term.” Select “Listing Types” from the dropdown menu and then check “Featured.” [box type="info"]You must have content in the Listings Taxonomy with the term “Featured” attached to it for the taxonomy to appear in the dropdown.[/box] The View is now filtering to display listings with the featured term attached to them.

b) Pagination

Because you only want to display 3 featured items on the homepage you need to use pagination to control this. Click “Edit” beside Pagination Select “Paged” from the dropdown menu and limit the number of results to 3: Click “Ok”

c) Layout

The layout defines the layout of the View. For the featured listings this should be a three column table. The field will include the listing-featured-item View Template. Click "Add Field." Choose the listing-featured-item shortcode.

d) Style

You can easily add styles to this by wrapping the code in a div. Click on “View/Edit HTML”. You’ll see that code has already been created for you. This can be styled very simply by wrapping it in a div: [code lang="html" wraplines="true"] <div id="wpv-front-page-slider"> {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <table width="100%"> <wpv-loop wrap="2" pad="true"> {{wpv-item index=1}} <tr><td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listings-slider-item"}}</td> {{wpv-item index=other}} <td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listings-slider-item"}}</td> {{wpv-item index=2}} <td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listings-slider-item"}}</td></tr> </wpv-loop> </table> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} </div> [/code] Click Publish.

6) Create View: Listings Slider

The Listings Slider is an attractive slider on the homepage that shows off content that you include in it by applying a taxonomy term. We’ll create this in a similar way to the “Featured Listings” View. Navigate to Views > Add New Call your View: Listings Slider Again, leave the shortcodes where they are. Here’s what we want to achieve with this View:
  • Filter listings by post date in a descending order
  • Filter for items in the Listing Taxonomies taxonomy with the “slider” term
  • Rollover pagination that slides to the next item after 5 seconds
  • Display the listings-slider-item View Template

a) Filter

Scroll down to View Query > Filter and click “edit”

You should select “Listings”, order by post date, descending. Now you need to filter to only show the “slider” items in the Listing Taxonomies taxonomy. Click “Add another filter term.” Select “Listing Types” from the dropdown menu, select “Any of the following” and then check “slider.”

b) Pagination

Again, the pagination needs to be adjusted. Click on “Edit” beside pagination. Set the pagination to Rollover with 1 item per page. Show each page for 5 seconds and slide left.

c) Layout

Now to control the layout of the slider. This is going to display one of our listings-slider-items at a time. Click “Add Field” Select the listings-slider-item View Template.

d) Style

Again, we can wrap this in a div to add some styles to the View. Click on “View/Edit HTML”. You’ll see some HTML there which you can apply styles to. We have just wrapped the code in a div but you can do something more complex should you wish. [code lang="html" wraplines="true"] <div id="wpv-front-page-slider"> {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <table width="100%"> <wpv-loop wrap="2" pad="true"> {{wpv-item index=1}} <tr><td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listing-slider-item"}}</td> {{wpv-item index=other}} <td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listing-slider-item"}}</td> {{wpv-item index=2}} <td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listing-slider-item"}}</td></tr> </wpv-loop> </table> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} </div> [/code]

7) Create View: Property Table

The final View that you need to create is a table listing all of the properties. You can see that in action here. Navigate to Views > Add New Call your View: property-table Again, leave the shortcodes where they are. Here’s what we want to achieve with this View:
  • Filter for listings by post date
  • Include a search box
  • Show all items (no pagination)
  • Create a table of fields to show important information
a) Filter Scroll down to View Query > Filter and click “edit” You should select “Listings”, order by post date, descending. Now we want to filter to only show the “slider” items in the Listing Taxonomies taxonomy. Click “Add another filter term.” This time you want to select “Post search” from the dropdown and check “Add a search box for visitors”.

b) Pagination

You do not need to amend the defaults for pagination.

c) Layout

The plan for this View is to display a list of all the listings. From the dropdown menu select “Table of Fields”. Ensure that “Include field names in table headings” is checked. Click “Add Field” You need to add the following fields with the following title and suffixes:
  • Title with a link: Title
  • Small-photo: Image (nb: this is a View Template)
  • Field - wpcf-square-feet – Size - (SQF)
  • Field - wpcf-price – Asking Price – (USD)

d) Style

Let’s add some styles to our table. Click on "View/Edit HTML": Here’s the HTML: [code lang="html"] {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <table width="100%"> <thead><tr> <th>{{wpv-heading name="post-link"}}Property{{/wpv-heading}}</th> <th>{{wpv-heading name="post-body"}}Image{{/wpv-heading}}</th> <th>{{wpv-heading name="post-field-wpcf-square-feet"}}Size{{/wpv-heading}}</th> <th>{{wpv-heading name="post-field-wpcf-price"}}Asking price{{/wpv-heading}}</th> </tr></thead> <tbody> <wpv-loop> <tr> <td>{{wpv-post-link}}</td> <td style="text-align:center;">{{wpv-post-body view_template="small-photo"}}</td> <td style="text-align:center;">{{wpv-post-field name="wpcf-square-feet"}} (SQF)</td> <td style="text-align:center;">{{wpv-post-field name="wpcf-price"}} (USD)</td> </tr> </wpv-loop> </tbody> </table> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} [/code] Click Publish.

8. Insert Views

We now need to insert the Views into some pages. We’ll need two Pages for this. Navigate to Pages > Add New. Create two pages:
  • Home
  • Main Listing
[box type="info"] To set the “Home” page as your homepage navigate to Settings > Reading and set it as the front page.[/box] On each of these pages you will need to insert a shortcode. To insert a shortcode click on the V icon on the editing screen. This will bring up a pop-up with your available shortcodes. On the Main Listing Page insert the property-table shortcode. On the Home page you need to insert the listings-slider shortcode, and the listings-featured shortcode. We’ve also added a heading over the listings-featured shortcode to give some context. Click Publish and your Real Estate site is ready! [box type="info"] If you’re a theme developer you can purchase the embeddable version of Views so you can create real estate themes with all of this going on under the bonnet, with none of the UI available to your clients and customers. [/box]

c) Layout

Now to control the layout of the slider. This is going to display one of our listings-slider-items at a time. Click “Add Field” Select the listings-slider-item View Template.

d) Style

Again, we can wrap this in a div to add some styles to the View. Click on “View/Edit HTML”. You’ll see some HTML there which you can apply styles to. We have just wrapped the code in a div but you can do something more complex should you wish. [code lang="html" wraplines="true"] <div id="wpv-front-page-slider"> {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <table width="100%"> <wpv-loop wrap="2" pad="true"> {{wpv-item index=1}} <tr><td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listing-slider-item"}}</td> {{wpv-item index=other}} <td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listing-slider-item"}}</td> {{wpv-item index=2}} <td>{{wpv-post-body view_template="listing-slider-item"}}</td></tr> </wpv-loop> </table> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} </div> [/code]

7) Create View: Property Table

The final View that you need to create is a table listing all of the properties. You can see that in action here. Navigate to Views > Add New Call your View: property-table Again, leave the shortcodes where they are. Here’s what we want to achieve with this View:
  • Filter for listings by post date
  • Include a search box
  • Show all items (no pagination)
  • Create a table of fields to show important information
a) Filter Scroll down to View Query > Filter and click “edit” You should select “Listings”, order by post date, descending. Now we want to filter to only show the “slider” items in the Listing Taxonomies taxonomy. Click “Add another filter term.” This time you want to select “Post search” from the dropdown and check “Add a search box for visitors”.

b) Pagination

You do not need to amend the defaults for pagination.

c) Layout

The plan for this View is to display a list of all the listings. From the dropdown menu select “Table of Fields”. Ensure that “Include field names in table headings” is checked. Click “Add Field” You need to add the following fields with the following title and suffixes:
  • Title with a link: Title
  • Small-photo: Image (nb: this is a View Template)
  • Field - wpcf-square-feet – Size - (SQF)
  • Field - wpcf-price – Asking Price – (USD)

d) Style

Let’s add some styles to our table. Click on "View/Edit HTML": Here’s the HTML: [code lang="html"] {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <table width="100%"> <thead><tr> <th>{{wpv-heading name="post-link"}}Property{{/wpv-heading}}</th> <th>{{wpv-heading name="post-body"}}Image{{/wpv-heading}}</th> <th>{{wpv-heading name="post-field-wpcf-square-feet"}}Size{{/wpv-heading}}</th> <th>{{wpv-heading name="post-field-wpcf-price"}}Asking price{{/wpv-heading}}</th> </tr></thead> <tbody> <wpv-loop> <tr> <td>{{wpv-post-link}}</td> <td style="text-align:center;">{{wpv-post-body view_template="small-photo"}}</td> <td style="text-align:center;">{{wpv-post-field name="wpcf-square-feet"}} (SQF)</td> <td style="text-align:center;">{{wpv-post-field name="wpcf-price"}} (USD)</td> </tr> </wpv-loop> </tbody> </table> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} [/code] Click Publish.

8. Insert Views

We now need to insert the Views into some pages. We’ll need two Pages for this. Navigate to Pages > Add New. Create two pages:
  • Home
  • Main Listing
[box type="info"] To set the “Home” page as your homepage navigate to Settings > Reading and set it as the front page.[/box] On each of these pages you will need to insert a shortcode. To insert a shortcode click on the V icon on the editing screen. This will bring up a pop-up with your available shortcodes. On the Main Listing Page insert the property-table shortcode. On the Home page you need to insert the listings-slider shortcode, and the listings-featured shortcode. We’ve also added a heading over the listings-featured shortcode to give some context. Click Publish and your Real Estate site is ready! [box type="info"] If you’re a theme developer you can purchase the embeddable version of Views so you can create real estate themes with all of this going on under the bonnet, with none of the UI available to your clients and customers. [/box]

When you need more than just posts and pages, Types provides the solution. Without any coding, you can create custom content types, organize content with taxonomies and customize editing screens using powerful custom fields. Download Now - It's FREE!

Define Custom Types

Go to Types > Custom Types and Taxonomy to create your new content type. You can control whether this custom type is visible (writers and editors can access it), or if it's private (used only by the PHP code). You can also add taxonomies to help organize your content.These can be hierarchical or flat taxonomies (similar to post categories and tags). Learn more about creating custom post types and creating custom taxonomies.

Create Unique Editing Screens with Custom Fields

Types provides you with a wide variety of custom fields, including check-boxes, text areas, images, drop-downs and many more. With these fields, you can customize the way different edit screens look for different content types. Types custom fields can also validate user-input. They check that the input is correctly added and correctly formatted. This means that when you use that data in your templates you know that the display will be flawless. Learn more about managing custom fields.

Display Custom Content Easily

Types makes it easy to insert your custom content. When creating content, authors can click on the T icon and insert any field into the content. If you want to include custom fields in themes, Types has got you covered. You can use the Types API to insert custom fields using PHP, or use Views to create dynamic templates (and more) without ever touching PHP.

Handle Existing Content

If you already have a large number of custom fields that you're managing manually, you can let Types take control. Tell Types what kinds of custom fields you have and they will each get their own fancy meta-boxes in the edit pages. This works great with custom fields that you've previously created , or that other custom field plugins have managed before.

Embed Into Your Themes and Plugins

If you're building themes and plugins, you can harness the power of Types and give your users a rich experience with WordPress. Types has an embedded mode which you can use to include the functionality in your themes and plugins. This means that you can define custom types and customize the editing interface without writing a single line of code. The embedded version runs as a theme function, not as a plugin. It doesn't require any activation. Also, because it doesn't include the Types GUI, it is much smaller than the full plugin version. Your users will still be able to customize things themselves if they download the Types plugin.

You can embed Types and Views in your themes and plugins. These versions include all the functionality, without the Admin configuration screens.
Once you have embedded Types and Views in your theme they are frozen there. This creates one monolithic code, which is not sensitive to either code or configuration changes.
  • Test, Export, Forget - you don't need to worry about Types and Views working differently after upgrades. When you export the version you're working on becomes part of your code. User sites cannot accidentally go wrong due to plugin auto-updates.
  • Protect from User Experiments - the embedded versions of Types & Views don't contain the configuration screens. Users cannot change the settings for Types and Views. They can take advantage of the functionality, create content, edit content and insert shortcodes. However, they cannot change the custom types, custom fields and Views that you have defined.
  • Retain flexibility - if your end-users ever want to access the configuration, they can always download and install the plugin version. This will give them access to the full Admin screens, allowing them to customize the site as they see fit.

You can embed Types and Views in your themes and plugins. These versions include all the functionality, without the Admin configuration screens.
Once you have embedded Types and Views in your theme they are frozen there. This creates one monolithic code, which is not sensitive to either code or configuration changes.
  • Test, Export, Forget - you don't need to worry about Types and Views working differently after upgrades. When you export the version you're working on becomes part of your code. User sites cannot accidentally go wrong due to plugin auto-updates.
  • Protect from User Experiments - the embedded versions of Types & Views don't contain the configuration screens. Users cannot change the settings for Types and Views. They can take advantage of the functionality, create content, edit content and insert shortcodes. However, they cannot change the custom types, custom fields and Views that you have defined.
  • Retain flexibility - if your end-users ever want to access the configuration, they can always download and install the plugin version. This will give them access to the full Admin screens, allowing them to customize the site as they see fit.

There are a number of ways to install a WordPress plugin. Plugins in the WordPress repository can be installed directly from the WordPress Dashboard. You can install Types and Views in two ways.

FTP

FTP (File Transfer Protocol) is a method used to transfer files to your server. To transfer files via FTP you will need a program such as FileZilla. This will make it easy for you to upload files to your WordPress installation.

1. Download the Plugin

Download the plugin you wish to install. Unzip it to your desktop.

2. Login to Your Server

Open your FTP program and fill in your login details. These will have been provided by your hosting provider.

3. Navigate to Your Plugin Folder

On the left hand side you will find your local files on your computer, and on the right you will find your remote server. In the remote server window navigate to your plugins folder. You will find this at …/wp-content/plugins/

4. Upload the Plugin

Drag and drop the plugin folder from your local site to your remote server.

5. Activate the Plugin

To activate the plugin login to your WordPress website and navigate to Plugins. Locate the Plugin and click “Activate”.

Upload via the Dashboard

You can also upload zip files to the WordPress Dashboard.

1. Login to WordPress

Navigate to Plugins > Add New Click “Upload”

2. Upload the File

Click “Choose File” and navigate to your zip file. You must upload the zip file to install a plugin from the dashboard, other file types will not work. Click “Install Now”.

3. Activate the Plugin

You’ll be taken to the activation page. Click “Activate Plugin.” Your plugin is now installed and ready to use.

This is a site for researchers of classical philosophy. It adresses the need for collaboration of german researchers in the branch of natural philosophy and comprises an introduction to natural philosophy, a list of current research projects in this area, a list of the responsible contacts - and most important a database of all the relevant publications in the area of natural philosophy. You can access this publications database via the navigation path: "Publikationen > Literaturliste" or directly at http://www.naturphilosophie.org/lit. The objectives achieved with this literature database using Types & Views are:
  • Ease the collection (entering) of publications containing all the metadata required for publications;
  • Enabling the users to sort the list of publications according to the column headings;
  • Enabling the users to use tags to restrict the number of publications displayed
  • Enabling the users to search for publications;
The search functionality needs to be enhanced in the near future with the following: Restrict the search to publications only, no other pages or any other post types should be returned.
  • Users shall be enabled to search for any part of publication, not just parts of the title (e.g. author, year of publication, type of publication, summary, reviews, etc.);
  • User shall be able to combine the tag cloud and free text search to narrow down the search results to only the hits that are relevant to them.
  • Publications are currently entered manually (redundant work) - we want to automate the process, since the data is already available in a text or xml format.

About this tutorial

You'll learn how to use Types and Views to create a fully-functional Showcase or Portfolio site with WordPress, without any coding. Video Overview (6 minutes)
This tutorial will show you how to build a showcase website with Types and Views. You can view the finished website here. We have built the website with the WordPress Twenty Eleven theme but you can use any theme to build your showcase.

What You Will Need

  • WordPress
  • Types
  • Views
  • WP-PostRatings Plugin
The final website will look like this: By including the WP-PostRatings Plugin you’re making it possible for your visitors to vote on your showcase. Before you can create your layout and design, you need to make some content types using Types. You can read our user guides about creating Custom Post Types, Custom Taxonomies and Custom Fields. Custom Post Type:Websites (Website(s)) Display Sections: Title, Editor Custom Taxonomy:Website Categories (Website Category(s)) Attached to: Websites Custom Field Group:Showcase: Displayed with: Websites
  1. Description - multiple lines
  2. URL - URL field
  3. Image - image field
Once you've created these content types you'll be able to use Views to display them.

1. Create a View Template for our Website Content

View Templates are similar to WordPress page templates, except you can create them using shortcodes, CSS and HTML, rather than having to code them using PHP. Custom Post Types are a way of distinguishing different types of content on your WordPress website. When you install WordPress you have two default content types:
  • Posts
  • Pages
Posts are the default content type that is used for blog posts. They are for dynamic content, with the first blog post displayed changing as a new one is added. Pages are the default WordPress content type that is used for static content. Unlike posts these are not time-specific. But Posts and Pages are not always enough. What if you want to create your own type of content? WordPress makes this possible with Custom Post Types. [box type="info"]Note: The phrase “Custom Post Types”, though widely used by WordPress developers is misleading. A Custom Post Type is a not a “post” in the traditional sense that WordPress uses. Custom Content Type would be more accurate. [/box] Custom Post Types are user defined and increase the flexibility of WordPress. You can create as many Custom Post Types as you want. Each Custom Post Type is a like a box that you put a specific type of content in. You’ll often find them being used in a variety of plugins – Products for eCommerce plugins, News for news plugins, for example. Perhaps you have an automotive sales site and you want a method for posting the cars you have for sale. Posts and Pages aren’t adequate and, besides, you want to use them for your Posts and Pages. You need to keep each type of content separate. With WordPress can create your own Custom Type called “Automotive” enabling you to have a specific content type for vehicles. This keeps them clearly distinguished from your Posts and Pages. You can also customize the different types of data that are associated with your Automotive content. This could be information about price, age, registration. And we can classify our automotives into different groupings with taxonomies.

What are Taxonomies?

To the average user, “taxonomy” seems like an odd word to use. But let’s take a look at the definition on dictionary.com
  • the science or technique of classification.
Taxonomies are a way of classifying your content. If you are already a WordPress user you have no doubt encountered the “Category” and “Tag” taxonomies. Category is a hierarchical taxonomy. Its default term is “Uncategorized”. As you use WordPress you add more terms to the taxonomy, which you then use to categorize your blog posts. As this taxonomy is hierarchical you can create terms and child terms. Like so: Tags are non-hierarchical. This means there are no parents or children – anything goes! Just type in your terms when you create your post. With Types you can create Custom Taxonomies, i.e. custom classifications your content. Let’s return to our car example. You have a Custom Type called “Automotive”, but there are lots of different forms of automotive out there. If you created Custom Post Types called “car”, “truck”, “motorcycle”, “buses” your site would soon become unwieldy. Instead you want to be able to group those that are similar together. Therefore, you create a taxonomy – vehicle. Within that taxonomy you define your terms. So: Vehicle
  • Car
  • Bus
  • Truck
  • Motorcycle
You also want to be able to classify them by color, so you create a taxonomy “color”. Color
  • Red
  • Blue
  • Green
  • Black
  • White
When you have created these custom taxonomies and associated them with your Custom Type, they will appear as options when a new piece of Automotive content is created.

Custom Post Types let you define a type of content.

Taxonomies classify that content. Organizing your content in this ways makes it easy for you, or your visitor, to search all of the automotive information and pull out the exact data that they want; a yellow sedan car, for example. There’s no limit to the number of Custom Post Types and Taxonomies that you can create. Proper usage of Custom Post Types and Taxonomies take WordPress far beyond a basic CMS, letting designers and developers run wild with their imaginations.

When you create a View you can choose a layout for it. This will provides the basis for how your View displays on the front end of your website. We have included five preset layouts which you can use as the starting point for your View. They are:
  • Unformatted
  • Table
  • Table of Fields
  • Ordered List
  • Unordered List

How View Layouts Work

On the Views admin screen you'll see the View Layout meta box. You can choose the layout that you want from the from the dropdown menu and the correct html code will be generated for you. By clicking on the "View/Edit Meta HTML" you can see the code and edit it. Here you can see the code that is generated for an ordered list, and how it related to the views loop: When you insert a field it is inserted into the code. In order to better understand how each layout works, it's best to look at an example output and the code. [box type="info"] Note: all of the layouts include additional shortcodes following the loop to ensure compatibility with WPML.[/box]

Unformatted

The unformatted layout adds no HTML to the layout. The only thing that it includes is the wpv-loop. This means you can insert any fields you want and create your own custom layout.

The Code

[html] {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <wpv-loop> </wpv-loop> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}{{wpml-string context="wpv-views"}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpml-string}}{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} [/html]

In Action

The slider that we created for the Magazine Theme uses an unformatted layout, you can see the details in this tutorial. The Slider View Template field was inserted and then we wrapped it in some divs.

Table

A table lays out items horizontally across the page. So if you choose a table with 2 columns, your data will be displayed as:
item 1 item 2
item 3 item 4
Each cell contains all of the fields. So if you have two fields in the table it will layout as:
item 1:field A item 1:field B item 2:field A item 2:field B item 3:field A item 3:field B
item 4:field A item 4:field B item 5:field A item 5:field B item 6:field A item 6:field B

The Code

[html] {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <table width="100%"> <wpv-loop wrap="2" pad="true"> {{wpv-item index=1}} <tr><td></td> {{wpv-item index=other}} <td></td> {{wpv-item index=2}} <td></td></tr> </wpv-loop> </table> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}{{wpml-string context="wpv-views"}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpml-string}}{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} [/html]

In Action

The Showcase Theme that we created in this tutorial uses a table layout. You can see in the below image that we've used two columns, and each field within the column uses a title and an image.

Table of Fields

A table of fields lays out the content vertically down the page so that each field has its own column. Like so:
Field A heading Field B heading
item 1:field A item 1:field B
item 2:field A item 2:field B
item 3:field A item 3:field B
item 4:field A item 4:field B
item 5:field A item 5:field B
item 6:field A item 6:field B

The Code

[html] {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <table width="100%"> <thead><tr> </tr></thead> <tbody> <wpv-loop> <tr> </tr> </wpv-loop> </tbody> </table> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}{{wpml-string context="wpv-views"}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpml-string}}{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} [/html]

In Action

The Real Estate Website that we created in this tutorial uses a table of fields for the layout of the property listings.

Ordered List

An ordered list generates <ol> and <li>/code> tags.

The Code

[html] {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <ol> <wpv-loop> <li></li> </wpv-loop> </ol> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}{{wpml-string context="wpv-views"}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpml-string}}{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} [/html]

In Action

This layout generates an ordered list. We haven't used this layout in any of our tutorials yet, but it could have been used in the Classifieds Tutorial to create an index. Here's how it would look:

Unordered List

The unordered list generates <ul> and <li> tags.

The Code

[html] {{wpv-layout-start}} <!-- wpv-loop-start --> <ul> <wpv-loop> <li></li> </wpv-loop> </ul> <!-- wpv-loop-end --> {{wpv-no-posts-found}}{{wpml-string context="wpv-views"}}<strong>No posts found</strong>{{/wpml-string}}{{/wpv-no-posts-found}} {{wpv-layout-end}} [/html]

In Action

The Classifieds website that you can learn to create in this tutorial uses an unordered list to display the directory on the homepage.

Types and Views perform complex operations and it's important to be able to debug its internals. We're using an advanced debugger, that can output and tell you what the code is doing.

Debug Output to Console

Add the following to your wp-config.php file: 
define('WPV_LOGGING_STATUS', 'info');
Then, open the console in your browser. In Google Chrome, click anywhere in the page and click on 'Inspect element'. Then, click on the 'Console' tab. [caption id="attachment_3462" align="aligncenter" width="666" caption="Views debugger"][/caption] The console panel shows you everything that happens to display this page. In this example, it starts by loading the View 'Todos'. Then, the View tells us that it loaded 3 posts (my 3 todos) and that it's calling the View Template for each of them. We can see the post ID that's loaded in each iteration.

PHP Debugging

In case you think that Types or Views are doing something wrong (what we call a bug), you should enable PHP error logging. Again, edit your wp-config.php file and add the following: 
ini_set('log_errors',TRUE);
ini_set('error_reporting', E_ALL);
ini_set('error_log', dirname(__FILE__) . '/error_log.txt');
This will produce a file called 'error_log.txt' in your WordPress root file. Make sure that the web browser can create and write this file. If it cannot, use an FTP program to create the file and make it writable to Apache (normally, user www-data).

Javascript Debugging

Many of the operations in WordPress require Javascript. Any error, due to anything, may cause all Javascript to stop and prevent things from happening. In Chrome, click on Tools->Javascript console. Normally, it should be clean. If you see any message, we should know about it.

Views lets you control the HTML output based on post content. You can craft complex expressions that evaluate values of different custom fields. Let's start with an example. I want to list todo items and strike-out items that are already completed. [caption id="attachment_3441" align="aligncenter" width="605" caption="Todos list with items striked"][/caption] You can see what I'm actually trying to do is wrap the title with <del> ... </del> tags. To do this, we need to check which todos are complete and add these tags around their titles - when we output the View (obviously, we don't mean to edit the title of the todo and add these tags to the database). Edit the View, go to the Layout section and click to edit the Meta HTML. [caption id="attachment_3444" align="aligncenter" width="531" caption="Meta HTML editor with conditional output"][/caption] This is the meta HTML segment that we used to produce the <del> tags around the title: [code lang="html"] {{wpv-if completed="wpcf-completed" evaluate="$completed = 1"}}<del>{{/wpv-if}} {{wpv-post-title}} {{wpv-if completed="wpcf-completed" evaluate="$completed = 1"}}</del>{{/wpv-if}} [/code] The wpv-if shortcodes are Views' way of executing conditional logic inside Views and View Templates. This is how it works: [code lang="html"] {{wpv-if arg1="FIELD1_NAME" arg2="FIELD2_NAME" arg3... evaluate="EXPRESSION USING ARG1, ARG2, ..." condition="true|false" debug="false|true"}} <conditional-HTML> {{/wpv-if}} [/code] The arguments can have any name that you choose. If you call the first argument 'arg1', you will use it as $arg1 in the evaluate expression. The condition (default=true) indicates the expected value of the evaluation. You can use 'false' values to display the output when the evaluate function fails. This way, you can implement if/else logic. The debug option lets you understand what's going on. It will output the error code, in case there is a problem parsing the expression in the evaluate function. Inside the evaluate expression, you can use any of the following:
  • Variables defined as shortcode parameters starting with a dollar sign
  • Integer and floating-point numbers
  • Math operators: +, -, *, /
  • Comparison operators: <, >, =, <=, >=, !=
  • Boolean operators: AND, OR, NOT
  • Nested expressions - several levels of brackets
  • empty() function that checks for blank or non-existing fields

Examples

Evaluate the value of a string field

[code lang="html"]{{wpv-if strfield="wpcf-somestrcustomfield" evaluate="$strfield = 'content'"}}[/code]

Check for ages larger than 13 and color green

[code lang="html"]{{wpv-if age="wpcf-age" color="wpcf-color" evaluate="($age > 13) AND ($color = 'green')"}}[/code]
Learn how to add conditional code to Views and Views Templates.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to add conditional code to Views and Views Templates.

What are Taxonomies?

Taxonomies are used in WordPress to classify content. The most common taxonomies that you will encounter are Categories and Tags. Terms are words or phrases within a taxonomy that can be applied to content. "Uncategorized", for example, is a term within the Category taxonomy. Categories are a hierarchical taxonomy. This means that there can be parent terms, so you can create a hierarchical structure. [caption id="attachment_321" align="aligncenter" width="292" caption="The Categories Non-Hierarchical Taxonomy"][/caption] Tags are a non-hierarchical taxonomy. These are simply added when you create your piece of content and do not have a structure. You can, however, create a tag cloud. [caption id="attachment_320" align="aligncenter" width="302" caption="The Tags Non-Hierarchical Taxonomy"][/caption] These distinctions are important to keep in mind when you plan your custom taxonomies.

What is a Custom Taxonomy?

A custom taxonomy is a taxonomy that is defined by you. It can be used to classify your content in a specific way, and is often attached to a custom post type. A real estate website, for example, might want to have the custom taxonomy "Property Type". With this set up your site visitors could easily filter information based on the type of property they want to view.

How to Create a Custom Taxonomy

With Types it's easy to create a custom taxonomy - it's just a matter of filling in the information. Let's take a look at how to create the "Property Type" taxonomy for a real estate website.

1. Give Your Taxonomy a Name

Navigate to Types > Custom Types and Taxonomies and click "Add Custom Taxonomy" You need to give your taxonomy a name and description. For this taxonomy I'm going to use the following details:
  • Taxonomy name plural - Property Types
  • Taxonomy name singular - Property Tyne
  • Slug - property-type

2. Choose your visibility

Here you can choose whether you want the taxonomy to appear in the WordPress Admin menu, or if you want to keep it hidden.

3. Select Post Types

You should associate your taxonomy with a post type. I have already created a "Property" post type for a real estate site. You can learn how to do that here. I'm going to associate my Property post type with the Property Types taxonomy.

4. Assign Labels

Labels are attached to your category name on the admin screen. Check one out in action: The defaults are usually fine for these but they are included here so that you can further customize your settings.

5. Advanced Settings

The advanced settings let you further tweak your taxonomy settings.Here is what they mean:
  • Rewrite - rewrite the permalinks. This will use what you have set up in settings > permalinks. You can also prepend your taxonomy name with a custom slug
  • Allow permalinks to be prepended with front base - lets the taxonomy be prepended with a custom slug (such as /blog/, /news/)
  • Hierarchical URLs - implements hierarchical URLs with hierarchical taxonomies. The means your URL could be /property-type/bungalow/3-bedroom/
  • show_ui - decide whether you want to display the UI to manage the taxonomy
  • show_in_nav_menus - determine whether you want to permit this taxonomy to be added to menus
  • show_tagcloud - enables the tag cloud widget for non-hierarchical taxonomies
  • hierarchical - this is an important option for determining the form of your taxonomy. A hierarchical taxonomy will behave the Category taxonomy, non-hierarchical will be like tags. For the Property Types category we'll choose hierarchical
  • query_var - uncheck to prevent queries
  • update_count_callback - use to write custom functions
Click save.

6. Add Terms

Your taxonomy will now appear underneath the Property post type. Navigate to Properties > Property Type Fill in your first term. I'm going to add "Apartment". Add as many terms as you wish - you're now ready to classify your post type!

What are Taxonomies?

Taxonomies are used in WordPress to classify content. The most common taxonomies that you will encounter are Categories and Tags. Terms are words or phrases within a taxonomy that can be applied to content. "Uncategorized", for example, is a term within the Category taxonomy. Categories are a hierarchical taxonomy. This means that there can be parent terms, so you can create a hierarchical structure. [caption id="attachment_321" align="aligncenter" width="292" caption="The Categories Non-Hierarchical Taxonomy"][/caption] Tags are a non-hierarchical taxonomy. These are simply added when you create your piece of content and do not have a structure. You can, however, create a tag cloud. [caption id="attachment_320" align="aligncenter" width="302" caption="The Tags Non-Hierarchical Taxonomy"][/caption] These distinctions are important to keep in mind when you plan your custom taxonomies.

What is a Custom Taxonomy?

A custom taxonomy is a taxonomy that is defined by you. It can be used to classify your content in a specific way, and is often attached to a custom post type. A real estate website, for example, might want to have the custom taxonomy "Property Type". With this set up your site visitors could easily filter information based on the type of property they want to view.

How to Create a Custom Taxonomy

With Types it's easy to create a custom taxonomy - it's just a matter of filling in the information. Let's take a look at how to create the "Property Type" taxonomy for a real estate website.

1. Give Your Taxonomy a Name

Navigate to Types > Custom Types and Taxonomies and click "Add Custom Taxonomy" You need to give your taxonomy a name and description. For this taxonomy I'm going to use the following details:
  • Taxonomy name plural - Property Types
  • Taxonomy name singular - Property Tyne
  • Slug - property-type

2. Choose your visibility

Here you can choose whether you want the taxonomy to appear in the WordPress Admin menu, or if you want to keep it hidden.

3. Select Post Types

You should associate your taxonomy with a post type. I have already created a "Property" post type for a real estate site. You can learn how to do that here. I'm going to associate my Property post type with the Property Types taxonomy.

4. Assign Labels

Labels are attached to your category name on the admin screen. Check one out in action: The defaults are usually fine for these but they are included here so that you can further customize your settings.

5. Advanced Settings

The advanced settings let you further tweak your taxonomy settings.Here is what they mean:
  • Rewrite - rewrite the permalinks. This will use what you have set up in settings > permalinks. You can also prepend your taxonomy name with a custom slug
  • Allow permalinks to be prepended with front base - lets the taxonomy be prepended with a custom slug (such as /blog/, /news/)
  • Hierarchical URLs - implements hierarchical URLs with hierarchical taxonomies. The means your URL could be /property-type/bungalow/3-bedroom/
  • show_ui - decide whether you want to display the UI to manage the taxonomy
  • show_in_nav_menus - determine whether you want to permit this taxonomy to be added to menus
  • show_tagcloud - enables the tag cloud widget for non-hierarchical taxonomies
  • hierarchical - this is an important option for determining the form of your taxonomy. A hierarchical taxonomy will behave the Category taxonomy, non-hierarchical will be like tags. For the Property Types category we'll choose hierarchical
  • query_var - uncheck to prevent queries
  • update_count_callback - use to write custom functions
Click save.

6. Add Terms

Your taxonomy will now appear underneath the Property post type. Navigate to Properties > Property Type Fill in your first term. I'm going to add "Apartment". Add as many terms as you wish - you're now ready to classify your post type!

What is a Custom Post Type?

Every content type in WordPress is a post (this includes posts and pages). Posts are containers for your content. A custom post type is a user created post type. The user (i.e. you) creates the post type. You can create custom post types by coding them in PHP, or you can use a plugin such as Types. Create a Custom Post Type with Types

Creating a custom post type is easy with Types. All you have to do is add the name and settings, and your new custom post type is ready. Let's take a look at how you can create a custom post type for a property letting website.

1. Name Your Custom Post Type

Go to Types > Custom Types and Taxonomies and click "Add New Custom Post Type". At the top you should add your name and description, along with your slug and a description For a Property website we can use the following:
  • Plural name - Properties
  • Singular name - Property
  • Slug - property
  • Description - Properties that we have available to rent

2. Determine Visibility

This option lets you determine whether your custom post type will appear in the WordPress Admin or not. As we want users such as authors and editors to be able to add property to the website we will make it visible. You can also change the menu positioning (i.e. where your custom post type will appear on the Admin menu - see the section on menu_position in the Codex for more information) and the icon.

3. Select Taxonomies

Taxonomies are used to categorize your post types. The most common WordPress taxonomies are categories and tags. [box type="info"]Read our introduction to Custom Post Types and Taxonomies to learn more or get your hands dirty with our tutorial on how to create a custom taxonomy.[/box] If you have created a custom taxonomies for your custom post type you can attach them here.

4. Choose Labels

Labels are the pieces of text that are attached to different areas of the admin screen, for example "Add New Property" or "No Property Found". [caption id="attachment_288" align="aligncenter" width="333" caption="An example of a label in use"][/caption] While the defaults often suffice, it can be useful to be able to tweak these labels to further customize your admin screen.

5. Choose Which Sections to Display

Types lets you choose which of the default WordPress sections you would like to display on the Add New/Edit Property page. These are:
  • Title - the title of the post type (selected by default)
  • Editor - the input text area (selected by default)
  • Comments - give author ability to turn comments on or off
  • Trackbacks - give author ability to turn trackbacks and pingbacks on or off
  • Author - add a dropdown menu for changing the post author
  • Excerpt - add a customized excerpt
  • Thumbnail - give the author the ability to upload a featured image
  • Custom-fields - add the custom fields input area
  • page-attributes - add the page attributes to allow author to change parent and template
  • post-formats - add post formats (such as aside, link, video)
[caption id="attachment_287" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="The post-format, thumbnail and page-atrribute sections on the admin screen"][/caption]

6. Tweak Advanced Settings

Advanced settings let you further tweak your custom post type. Normally the defaults should suffice but in case you want to amend them here is what they do:
  • Rewrite - rewrite post types permalinks. You can use the normal WordPress URL logic (which you will have set up in Settings > Permalinks) or you can use a custom URL format. The default for this is "true" and it will use the slug you defined earlier.
  • Allow permalinks to be prepended with front base - if you are prepending your permalinks with a phrase such as /blog/ selecting this will also prepend your new custom post type with this phrase e.g. /blog/property/
  • Feeds - choose whether to publish a feed for this post type. It will default to the has_archive setting (see below) but this give you ability to turn off feeds while keeping an archive page.
  • Pages - is the custom post type a dynamic (post) or static (page) piece of content
  • has_archive - determine whether the post type has an archive page or not.
  • show_in_menu - determine whether you want your post type to show in the admin menu or not.
  • show_ui - generates the user interface for the post type. If you don't want a UI  you should uncheck this.
  • publicly_queryable - determine whether post type queries can be performed from the front end.
  • exclude_from_search - check this if you want to exclude your post type from search results.
  • hierarchical - lets parents be specified.
  • can_export - allow this post type to be exported.
  • show_in_nav_menus - determine whether this post type is available for inclusion in navigation menus
  • query_var - allow or prevent queries
  • Permalink epmask - add an endpoint to your custom post type. See here for more info.
When you are happy with your settings click save. Your Property post type will now be available on the WordPress admin menu.

What are Custom Fields?

Custom Fields are extra pieces of information (also known as meta-data) that can be attached to a post type. Examples of these could be:
  • Date Released
  • Property Type
  • Price
  • Special Conditions
This meta-data is handled with key/value pairs:
  • key - name of the element
  • value - the value attached to that element
For example:
  • Date released (key)/1st Feb 2012 (value)
  • Property Type (key)/ Bungalow (value)
  • Price (key) / $9.99 (value)
  • Special conditions (key) / No pets (value)
You can implement WordPress custom fields by coding them using PHP - there is information in the WordPress Codex about how to do this.

Creating Custom Fields with Types

You don't have to know PHP to create a Custom Field. You can also use a plugin such as Types. This method takes care of all of the coding for you, so you can simply get on with planning your website. Let's take a simple example of a Property Letting website to take a look at an example of how to create custom fields with Types.

1. Planning

Before you get started with creating custom fields, it's a good idea to plan what type of data you would like to be attached to your content. For a Property Letting website a good place to start would be with the following keys:
  • Weekly Rental Price
  • State
  • Date available
  • Parking
  • Property Type
  • Images
  • Floorplan
  • Restrictions

2. Create Custom Fields

To create a Custom Field using Types, go to Types > Custom Fields and click "Add New Group" [box type="info"] With Types you can group custom fields together into custom field groups. Then you can attach that group to a custom post type. [/box] On the left hand side of the dashboard you can give a name and description to your custom field group, on the right you will see the available fields. The available fields are the different types of custom fields available. Different types of meta-data will require different types of field. For this property example you might want to use the following:
  • Weekly Rental Price - Numeric
  • State - Select
  • Number of bedrooms - Numeric
  • Date available - Date
  • Parking - Checkbox
  • Property type - Select
  • Images - Image
  • Floorplan - File Upload
  • Restrictions - Single Line
You can see how different data types require different formats. This ultimately helps your data to be organized efficiently in your database so that you can easily apply filters to it. To create a custom field click on the available field that you require, this will add the field to your group: To create a "Weekly Rental Price" custom field click on "Numeric" and add the required information. [box type="info"] You can require validation for any custom field. This means that a content type will not be published until that custom field is completed. This helps to ensure that you do not have any incomplete listings. [/box] The same process is followed for all the rest until your custom field groups look something like this: [box type ="info"] Drag and drop your custom fields to re-order them. [/box]

3. Attach Custom Field Group

You can attach your custom field group to any post type or taxonomy. This includes default WordPress post types (post & page) or any custom post type you have already created. For this example you can attach it to the Property post type. This means that all of your custom fields will be associated with that type of content. You can see the custom fields appearing on the property post type creation screen: [box type="info"] Use shortcodes to insert custom field data into your post to display that data. You can use Views to create a template that can be applied to all of a specified custom post type. [/box]

What are Custom Fields?

Custom Fields are extra pieces of information (also known as meta-data) that can be attached to a post type. Examples of these could be:
  • Date Released
  • Property Type
  • Price
  • Special Conditions
This meta-data is handled with key/value pairs:
  • key - name of the element
  • value - the value attached to that element
For example:
  • Date released (key)/1st Feb 2012 (value)
  • Property Type (key)/ Bungalow (value)
  • Price (key) / $9.99 (value)
  • Special conditions (key) / No pets (value)
You can implement WordPress custom fields by coding them using PHP - there is information in the WordPress Codex about how to do this.

Creating Custom Fields with Types

You don't have to know PHP to create a Custom Field. You can also use a plugin such as Types. This method takes care of all of the coding for you, so you can simply get on with planning your website. Let's take a simple example of a Property Letting website to take a look at an example of how to create custom fields with Types.

1. Planning

Before you get started with creating custom fields, it's a good idea to plan what type of data you would like to be attached to your content. For a Property Letting website a good place to start would be with the following keys:
  • Weekly Rental Price
  • State
  • Date available
  • Parking
  • Property Type
  • Images
  • Floorplan
  • Restrictions

2. Create Custom Fields

To create a Custom Field using Types, go to Types > Custom Fields and click "Add New Group" [box type="info"] With Types you can group custom fields together into custom field groups. Then you can attach that group to a custom post type. [/box] On the left hand side of the dashboard you can give a name and description to your custom field group, on the right you will see the available fields. The available fields are the different types of custom fields available. Different types of meta-data will require different types of field. For this property example you might want to use the following:
  • Weekly Rental Price - Numeric
  • State - Select
  • Number of bedrooms - Numeric
  • Date available - Date
  • Parking - Checkbox
  • Property type - Select
  • Images - Image
  • Floorplan - File Upload
  • Restrictions - Single Line
You can see how different data types require different formats. This ultimately helps your data to be organized efficiently in your database so that you can easily apply filters to it. To create a custom field click on the available field that you require, this will add the field to your group: To create a "Weekly Rental Price" custom field click on "Numeric" and add the required information. [box type="info"] You can require validation for any custom field. This means that a content type will not be published until that custom field is completed. This helps to ensure that you do not have any incomplete listings. [/box] The same process is followed for all the rest until your custom field groups look something like this: [box type ="info"] Drag and drop your custom fields to re-order them. [/box]

3. Attach Custom Field Group

You can attach your custom field group to any post type or taxonomy. This includes default WordPress post types (post & page) or any custom post type you have already created. For this example you can attach it to the Property post type. This means that all of your custom fields will be associated with that type of content. You can see the custom fields appearing on the property post type creation screen: [box type="info"] Use shortcodes to insert custom field data into your post to display that data. You can use Views to create a template that can be applied to all of a specified custom post type. [/box]

Building a View

Let's start by creating a new View for listing properties on our acme-housing home page.

1. Create a New View

Go to Views > Add New. Give your View a name. A View includes these parts:
  • Title – the name of the view. This helps you identify the View and is not displayed on public pages.
  • Body – contains the final output of the view. You can add your own HTML and shortcodes. By default, the body contains the filter and layout sections (we'll explain more about them shortly).
  • Query – controls what content the View loads from the database
  • Layout – controls how the View displays the content

2. Query the database

The first thing to do is tell Views what type of content you want to get from the database. You can load a single post type or taxonomy, and multiple post types and taxonomies.

Filter by Post Type

Views will detect all of the post types and custom post types available in your WordPress installation. You can check out our Real Estate and Showcase Tutorials so see some examples of websites you can build that filter by Post Type.

Filter by Taxonomy

Views will also detect all of the taxonomies available in your WordPress installation.

Filters

Once you have chosen what you want to load, you can use filters to fine-tune content selection. Views includes a wide range of filters. You can filter content by status, by custom field values, taxonomy or hierarchy. Add as many filters as needed to zoom into the exact content you want to load. When you add filters, you can allow for additional filtering by site visitors, by adding a search box, for example.

3. Set Pagination

Next, choose how much data to display. You can show all results, or enable pagination. Pagination means that query results are broken into pages and users will be able to scroll between them. When pagination is enabled, you can switch pages using full-page refresh or AJAX refresh. AJAX refresh allows you to build fancy sliders with transition effects using Views.

4. Choose your Layout

Once you've decided what content you want to display, it's time to decide how to display it. The Layout section lets you choose how to show the content. You can choose between one of the preset layouts or create your very own. Preset layouts include unformatted, table and lists. Choose one of them and select which fields to include. To display your View you will need to insert the shortcode into a page or post. Go to Pages > Add New. Click on the V icon and select the "properties" shortcode. Click "Publish." Your content should now be displayed just how you want it.

What is a View Template?

View templates let you control the visual appearance of content. For example, imagine you're doing a real estate website. Each property would have its own page with an image, description, price range, property type and other essential information. You want all property pages to have the same layout, but each with its unique content. WordPress has a robust template system that allows to achieve just that, but it requires extensive coding and knowledge of the WordPress API. Even if you're fluent in PHP and know WordPress inside and out, chances are your client isn't. This means that whatever you build, you will need to maintain and tweak indefinitely. Views takes a different approach to templates. We've created View Templates. These are 'soft' templates, which you can create from the WordPress admin. All it takes is knowledge of HTML and CSS. Views will take care of the technical details and let you both insert and style different fields.

Create a View Template

Let's create a simple View Template for a real estate website. To create a dynamic template with Views, navigate to View Templates > Add New.

1. Name your View Template

The View Template editor looks like an ordinary WordPress page, but it is actually for creating your template Like any WordPress post or page, you can use either the visual editor or the HTML mode. Any text, or HTML, that you enter will appear on any post type that uses this template. I'm going to call this View Template "Property Single Page Template".

2. Add Fields

To add content fields, click on the V icon at the top. You'll see a list of all the available fields. Click on any field to insert it to the template. We'll add the image, description, location and price fields. These will come from the custom fields that have been attached to the property post type. We'll also add the body field. The body is what authors enter in the main text for the property. Click on the V icon and select the fields you wish to insert. The shortcodes will appear in your text area.

3. Style the Template

However, it's not enough to simply add the fields. If you leave it as it is your content will look something like this: To style your short codes you need to apply CSS classes to them using HTML DIV elements. You can do this in the HTML editor. Ideally you should include the CSS in your theme files (in style.css, or using @import). You can add inline CSS but it is not recommended.

4. Attach to a Post Type

Whether you want to style your default WordPress content types, or your custom content types, it's easy to attach your template to a post type. You can learn how to create a custom post type here. To do this navigate to Views > Settings

5. Add Content

Add content to your Property post type and you'll be able to see your new View Template in action.

We're excited to announce a release candidate of Types and Views 0.9.5. This version is the result of two months of intense development by the entire team and brings a host of new features, improvements and a few fixes. As always, our goal is to let you build even richer sites with Types and Views and do it easier. When we asked you about repeater fields, we received a huge amount of feedback, which helped us craft the new features for this release. After careful review, we concluded that field arrays for the 'parent' post don't sit well with how Types and Views work. We dug in deeper and came up with our own architecture for implementing arrays of related information. Many of the sample uses talked about examples such as artists who have shows, products that have benefits and other things that look awfully close to parent /child relationship between different posts. [caption id="attachment_6786" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Agreements, connecting people and cars"][/caption] So, in order to build even stronger infrastructure, we decided to add a complete framework for parent /child relationship to both Types and Views. As before, Types defines the relationship and Views takes care of the display. To achieve the same functionality as repeater fields, which belong to one post type, we've added a way to make one post type the parent of another AND to edit the child posts right from within the parent post editor. This provides the convenient editing for repeating information, but doesn't sacrifice database integrity on the way.

Post relationship

With Types 0.9.5, when you edit a custom post type definition, you'll see a new 'post relationship' section. [caption id="attachment_7010" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Post relationship box"][/caption] Once you've made one post the child of another, you open a whole new set of possibilities.
  • You can edit child posts from within the parent editing (see Field Tables below).
  • When you edit a child post, you can indicate who it belongs to, using a parent drop-down.
  • When you display parent posts with a View, you can display the fields of the child posts.
There's already a manual page about post relationship. It shows a simple example of a house that has rooms (but these rooms can also have furniture) and a more complex, but very realistic example, of a car-hire site. When you define post relationship you allow one post to point to another. You can use this relationship to display fields that belong to the parents.

Field Tables

Now that you've defined relationships between posts, it's time to put them to good use. First, you'd probably like to add some custom fields to the child posts. Then, you'll be able to edit the child posts and their custom fields, in a neat table, directly from the parent post. [caption id="attachment_6658" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Editing child items from the parent post"][/caption] But wait, is this thing exactly like repeater fields? Not really. There's a whole lot more to editing child posts in a table. A child post can belong to different parents. In our car-hire example, agreements belong to both a person and a car. When you edit a person, you'd like to see all the rental agreements that he has. When you edit a car, you should see all the renters that this car had or are scheduled to have. The 'rental agreement' type may have many fields. Not all are relevant for different parents, so Types lets you choose which fields to display when editing different parents. You should read more about bulk editing with Field Tables to see how it works and what you can achieve.

Displaying child contents (Field Tables)

So, we've added a way to define post relationship and to edit child posts from the parents. Now, we just need a nice way to display all this information. Views 0.9.5 can query and filter posts according to their parents. When you create a new View and the post type you're querying has parents, you can choose to filter by those parents. Like with ordinary WordPress pages, you can filter by the current parent or the parent set by the View. I hope that this last sentence doesn't confuse for too long. The meaning is that you can easily have nested Views, showing child fields. For example, if you're showing houses, each house can have a child View for the rooms. This manual page about displaying child items explains how to easily display them using either a View, or with the new PHP API in Types 0.9.5.

Performance

It's always fun to optimize our code and make it run faster. It's especially fun when we ourselves depend on it for our production server on both wp-types.com and wpml.org. This release sees a big performance boost in two places:
  • In the WordPress admin, we're doing far fewer SQL queries in the post-edit and in Types setup pages.
  • AJAX page loads are now running without calling wp-admin and are cache-able. Just for figures, on our own 8-core dedicated server, this brings it down from 2.5 seconds to less than 0.1 second. If you're using AJAX updates in your Views, you're going to feel the improvement immediately.

Streamlined interface

Between all the shiny new features, performance improvements and bug fixes, this is actually my favorite new thing in Types and Views 0.9.5. I'm acting as our webmaster. This means that I create new Views and View Templates. I have a few other daily tasks, so I really like it when my webmaster role takes as little time as possible (and I can run the business). Until this release, the field-insert popup dialog (which you get when you click on 'insert field' or the V icons) was a little cluttered. It could be a lot cluttered if you have lots of custom fields in the site (like we do). To me, this was a big problem. I know what I want to insert, but I had to spend 3 minutes just finding it on the screen. [caption id="attachment_7029" align="aligncenter" width="300" caption="Only relevant fields show in popups"][/caption] Views now does its best to eliminate options and show you only relevant fields. When you create a View, it knows exactly which content types you're using. For View Templates, it shows everything, but much more orderly. Then, there's that little search box. Try it by typing anything. You'll see the fields list immediately adjust and irrelevant fields drop away. After entering just a couple of characters, you'll immediately see the field you want to insert.

Stability

Since we had ample time to develop and review this release, we feel that it's the most stable release to-date. It's the first time that we managed to pass Types and Views through our complete QA cycle. This helped reveal numerous bugs, ranging from tiny wording issues to PHP bugs. Types and Views 0.9.5 are already powering our own sites and we're very happy with how it works for us.

Bug fixes

Most bugs were difficult to get to, and are even more difficult to explain. However, there are a couple of things that stand out:
  • WPML integration - now that wp-types.com is turning multilingual, we noticed a few places where Views was pulling items in the wrong language from the database.
  • Fields not rendering - this is somewhere in the middle between Types and WordPress core. Since we can't control WordPress, we fixed it all on our side. Types will now insert fields that are 100% compatible with how WordPress parses shortcodes, eliminating the possibility of fields not being displayed.

Getting Types and Views 0.9.5

You can download Types 0.9.5 from the WordPress download page or from your wp-types account. Views 0.9.5 is only available to Views clients. Please login to your wp-types.com account and click on Downloads. We've done a ton of testing on these versions and they are already powering our sites. However, it's a major update, so before updating live sites, please please backup your database.
